title: 110_s3659
content: The Corporate Transparency Act of 2007 may be cited as the "Corporate Transparency Act". It requires disclosure of book-tax differences to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Corporate Transparency Act of 2007, also known as the "Corporate Transparency Act", mandates the disclosure of book-tax differences to the Securities and Exchange Commission. This includes the disclosure of return information of specified public entities for the reconciliation of financial income statements reported to the SEC with income tax. The Securities and Exchange Commission receives return information of specified public entities for reconciliation of financial income statements with income tax. Officers and employees can only use this information for civil enforcement, administration of securities laws, and conducting a study required by the Corporate Transparency Act of 2007. The term 'specified public entity' refers to entities issuing registered securities under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and required to file schedule M-3. For affiliated groups filing consolidated returns, the term applies to the group as a whole. Amendments are made to procedures and record-keeping related to disclosure under section 6103 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new provisions (21) in certain sections. These amendments will apply to requests made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6104A. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN CORPORATE BOOK-TAX DIFFERENCES. New provisions in the Internal Revenue Code require disclosure of corporate book-tax differences. The Secretary is required to make information about specified entities publicly available, including their name, address, CUSIP identification number, and total net income from the worldwide consolidated income statement for each taxable year. The total net income (or loss) of foreign entities included on the income statement but not on the consolidated tax return, adjustments reflecting differences in income, and total income of entities on both the income statement and consolidated tax return are required to be disclosed. Additionally, the total net income (or loss) on the consolidated tax return for the specified entity must be included. The specified entity must disclose total temporary and permanent differences between certain items on the consolidated income tax return for the taxable year. The term 'specified entity' refers to any entity required to file schedule M-3, or an affiliated group filing a consolidated return. Sec. 6104A requires public disclosure of corporate book-tax differences. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment date. SEC. 4 imposes penalties for failure to file accurate information on corporate book-tax differences. The amendment to Section 6652 of the Internal Revenue Code imposes penalties for failure to file information on corporate book-tax differences by specified entities. Penalties are imposed on specified entities for failure to file information on corporate book-tax differences. The amount to be paid varies based on the total assets of the entity at the end of the taxable year. Penalties for failure to file information on corporate book-tax differences vary based on the total assets of the entity at the end of the taxable year. For entities with total assets between $250,000,000 and $1,000,000,000, the penalty is $50,000, and for entities with total assets exceeding $1,000,000,000, the penalty is $100,000. For entities other than corporations, penalties range from $5,000 to $10,000 based on gross receipts. Penalties for failure to file information on corporate book-tax differences are based on gross receipts for specified entities. The penalties range from $10,000 to $100,000 depending on the gross receipts for the taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to returns and statements filed after the enactment date of this Act for specified entities with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000. SEC. 5. STUDY ON BOOK-TAX DISCLOSURES. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the SEC and Joint Committee on Taxation, will conduct a study on reconciling financial income statements with tax returns. The study will address the need for additional reporting of book-tax differences to the IRS and SEC, as well as the benefits and risks of publicly disclosing such differences. A report must be submitted within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit a report to Congress on matters studied under the Act, along with any recommendations. The term "specified entity" is defined as per section 6104A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
